name: Apology Hedge
description: Messages that lead with unnecessary apologies or self-blame before asking/saying something. Look for phrases like “sorry to bother,” “my bad,” “I’m probably missing something,” used as a preface rather than to correct a real mistake.
examples: Sorry to bother—quick question: where is the config for the staging DB connection?
My bad if this is obvious, but how do I run the full test suite locally?
Sorry, I might be misunderstanding—should this endpoint return 401 or 403?
persona: Anxious Junior Developer (afraid to ask for help)

name: Over-Justifying
description: Asks for help but adds lots of extra explanation to defend the question (what they already tried, why they’re asking, why they’re blocked) in a way that’s longer than needed. It reads like they’re proving they “deserve” help.
examples: I’ve been digging into this for a while and tried changing the env vars, restarting Docker, and re-pulling images, but I still get the same error—am I missing a step to get migrations running?
I know everyone’s busy and I’ve read the docs + searched Slack, but I can’t find where we define the feature flags—could someone point me to the file?
I don’t want to waste anyone’s time, but after trying three different approaches and rereading the PR, I’m still not sure why the CI job is failing—any ideas?
persona: Anxious Junior Developer (afraid to ask for help)

name: Vague Help Ask
description: Requests help without a clear question or concrete details, making it hard to respond. Look for broad asks like “anyone know what’s wrong?” or “can someone help?” without error text, what they’re trying to do, or the exact decision needed.
examples: Can someone help me with this? It’s not working.
Anyone know what I’m doing wrong here?
I’m stuck on the build—any suggestions?
persona: Anxious Junior Developer (afraid to ask for help)

name: Hard Commit
description: Messages that make an unqualified promise about delivery (date/feature/outcome) with definitive language and no caveats—e.g., “will,” “guaranteed,” “locked,” “100%,” or exact dates—even when scope sounds uncertain.
examples: Yep — we’ll have the new onboarding flow shipped by Friday EOD, guaranteed.
No worries, we can definitely include SSO + audit logs in this release. Consider it locked.
I’ve confirmed we’ll hit 99.99% uptime starting next week.

name: Scope Creep
description: Messages that add extra features or requirements on top of what was discussed in the same message (often with “while we’re at it,” “also,” “quick add”) without acknowledging tradeoffs, time, or resourcing.
examples: We’ll ship the dashboard redesign next sprint — and while we’re at it, let’s add custom filters + export to CSV.
Let’s do the pricing page refresh. Also can we sneak in the new trial flow and the referral banner? Should be quick.
We’re fixing the search bug; might as well improve ranking, add synonyms, and build a new empty-state too.

name: Unverified Assurance
description: Statements that present assumptions as facts: “already approved,” “engineering said yes,” “legal is fine,” “customers will love it,” without citing a source, link, or confirmation (no “I think/maybe”).
examples: Engineering is good with this approach — we can start building today.
Legal already signed off on the new tracking events, so we’re clear to launch.
This will definitely reduce churn by 10% once it goes out.

name: Abrupt Commands
description: Messages that are mostly directives with no greeting, softener, or collaboration language. Look for imperatives (“do X”, “ship it”), short sentences, and lack of “please/can we” or any rationale.
examples: Fix the failing build and redeploy. Now.
Get me the numbers by EOD. Don’t overthink it.
Stop the rollout. Revert and open a postmortem doc.

name: Public Callouts
description: Calling out a person or team in a channel in a corrective/blaming way. Look for @mentions paired with criticism or “why didn’t you…” phrasing, especially in public channels instead of a neutral request.
examples: @maria why is the API still timing out? This has been broken all morning.
@backend this is the third time we’ve missed the SLA this week. What are you doing?
@jon you said this would be done Friday. It’s Monday. Explain.

name: Dismissive Replies
description: Responses that shut down discussion without engaging the content. Look for terse negations or minimizing phrases like “no”, “not happening”, “whatever”, “obviously”, “don’t care”, with little or no explanation.
examples: No. That’s not the right approach.
We’re not debating this. Just ship it.
This is obvious. Read the doc and stop pinging me.
